Problem:
Consider a dynamic model where the temperature of a system \\( T \\) is governed by the heat equation \\( \\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\nabla^2 T \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is the thermal diffusivity. We investigate the effect of an initial condition modification characterized by \\( T(x,0) = T_0 + h(x) \\), where \\( h(x) \\) is a heat source distribution function.

If we start with the modified initial condition \\( T(x,0) = T_0 + h(x) \\) and allow the system to evolve according to the heat equation without any intervention, will the temperature distribution \\( T(x,t) \\) at a later time \\( t \\) be the same as if it started from \\( T_0 \\) only?
Explanation: The presence of the heat source distribution \\( h(x) \\) alters the initial temperature distribution, thus changing the evolution of the heat equation. The solution \\( T(x,t) \\) will not be the same as the one starting with \\( T_0 \\) due to the influence of \\( h(x) \\) on the diffusion process.
